channel.title: Computer Drive Name's
channel.description: Well recently I got a new laptop that I have been building up to be a just coding computer and so far I have put a decent amount of work into modifying windows xp to suit my need's but one thing I failed to notice is that when I installed xp in the first place (was preloaded with windows 7) I had changed the dive name from C to I. Now it's nothing major but it gets quite annoying when installers mainly install to the C drive, is there anyway to change this without completely re installing and formatting the drive back to C because doing so would lose about a weeks worth of edits and free lanced coding.

item.title: Computer Drive Name's
item.dc:creator: @mcbeans mcbeans
item.description:
@mcbeans wrote:

[quote=“Andrew Ferguson, post:5, topic:408379”][quote author=noobs are ftw link=topic=509662.msg3698202#msg3698202 date=1312580121]
go use linux its 100x better
[/quote]
I have a desktop with more dedicated ram and a higher speed connection for linux that I use for higher level coding. This ones mainly for when I’m on the road or on flights when I just want to get some work done for either my company or working on firmware for my phone and the few apps I update on android market.

how about not use xp? windows 7 has an XP mode that you can download for free. Xp is the worst OS i’ve ever used, and this comes from someone who is a dedicated windows person.

Well window’s seven may be visually pleasurable the way it is built is basically for social networking and gaming. It also has more restrictions on the way that you can edit the system and is more protective of system files. Window’s xp will always be better then seven for coding reasons because of it’s simplicity (windows xp professional at least).

OT I made a back up online of my files, had to re install due to the system file’s.[/quote] i wholly agree, but you can run xp inside of windows 7, cause xp is soooo damn laggy

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Drive Name's
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

Found this on a website.
"Start Here:
1). Start Menu
2). Run
3). type “control” (with out quotation marks)
4). go to “Administrative Tools”
5). go to “Computer Management”
6). click the little “+” beside “Storage”
7). click “Disk Management”
8). if there is already a drive with the letter “c:” right click on it (in the top right window) and change it to some other arbitrary letter (it doesn’t matter which one really)
9). Then right-click on the hard drive and change it to c:\

Now if this does not work follow these steps
1). Go back into your control panel
2). Click “System”
3). go to the “Hardware Tab” (up top)
4). Click “Device Manager” (about half way down window)
5). Click the ‘+’ beside “Disk Drives”
6). There should be your harddrive, right click it and go to “Uninstall”
7). Click “ok” in the box that pops up, then restart

When it restarts it should automatically rename it to C:\ (it will automatically reinstall itself when you restart)"

Read full topic
